original_title: An Android Phone Powers A Self Driving Car
original_content:
As auto manufacturers have brought self-driving features to their products, were told about how impressive their technologies are and just how much computing power is on board to make it happen. Thus it surprised us (and it might also surprise you too) that some level of self-driving can be performed by an Android phone. [Mankaran Singh] has the full details.
It starts with the realization that a modern smartphone contains the necessary sensors to  perform basic self-driving, and then moves on to making a version of openpilot that can run on more than the few supported phones. Its not the driver-less car of science fiction but one which performs what we think is SAE level 2 self driving, which is cruise control, lane centering, and collision warning. They take it out on the road in a little Suzuki on a busy Indian dual carriageway in the rain, and while we perhaps place more trust in meat-based driving, it does seem to perform fairly well
Self driving features are codified into a set of levels for an easy reference on what each is capable of doing. Weve taken a look at it in the past, should you be interested.
title: Androidスマートフォンでのセルフドライビング可能、詳細は？
body: 自動車メーカーが自動運転機能を搭載する中、Android搭載スマートフォンでも自動運転が可能であることがわかった。SAEレベル2に相当するクルーズコントロール、レーンセンタリング、衝突警告機能に成功、雨のインドの道路でテストした結果は良好だった。
titles: Androidスマートフォンでのセルフドライビング可能、詳細は？
openpilotを使用して、複数のスマートフォンで自動運転が可能に
SAEレベル2の自動運転で基本的な運転を実現！
雨降りのインドの道路、少し小型の車で自動運転テストを実施
自動運転のレベル分けとは？-SAEレベルの基礎知識-
